title: Filters
content:
Filters help you filter record lists or define filters for a report. You can use the following methods to create a filter.

Filter by field value

  1. Click the Add filter button.

    • In record lists, this button is located above the list of records.
    • When you create a report, this button appears when you select the record type for the report.

    If there are more records than the Maximum query size value defined in the tenant settings from Suite Administration (default: 10, 000), the Filter wizard is displayed. The Add Filter button is located above the Filter wizard. For information about using the Filter wizard, see Filters below.

  2. From the Select field list, select a field and a value, by which to filter the list:

    • List fields

    • Record fields

    • Text fields

    • Date fields

    • The fields that are initially available in the filter are searchable fields. After you select the first searchable field, fields that aren't defined as searchable fields become available for filtering as well. Searchable fields are defined in the metadata for the record type.
    • If all searchable fields are removed from the filter, the non-searchable fields are removed as well.
    • Filtering isn't supported for encrypted fields.

    • List fields

      For fields that have defined sets of values, the values are displayed and you can select one or more values by which to filter the records. For example, select the Priority field, and select Critical and High to show only critical and high changes in the filtered list.

      You can click the button and select Is to apply a positive filter or Is not to apply a negative filter (which filters by all options except the selected ones).

      The filter definition must include at least one positive filter. Therefore, the button doesn't appear initially in the first filter you select. It appears in the next filter you select. If you select a positive filter for the second one and then click the first filter, the button appears in that filter and you can select Is or Is not.

      If it is a multi-select list, you can also choose operators as shown below.

      • The default filter is the positive filter.
      • This option isn't available in the filter in the History tab.

    • Record fields

      For fields whose values are derived from record lists, click the list box, and select one or more values from the list. For example, in Change Management, in the filter, select the Owner field, and select one or more owners to show in the filtered list.

      When you create and share an operational report or a view, if the filter field is a person record type such as the Owner field, you can select Me (for example, Me (Aaron Caffery)) to create a dynamic filter based on the user currently logged in. If you want to create a filter with a fixed value, select your actual user name (for example, Aaron Caffery) instead of Me.

      Alternatively, you can filter the records by a particular field of the selected record type. At the bottom of the list of fields, click By <record type> fields.

      Fields related to the record type are displayed.

      Select a property by which to filter the records. For example, Location. Then select values for the filter, according to the type of field you selected. For example, France and Netherlands.

      You can click the button and select Is to apply a positive filter or Is not to apply a negative filter (which filters by all options except the selected ones).

      The filter definition must include at least one positive filter. Therefore, the button doesn't appear initially in the first filter you select. It appears in the next filter you select. If you select a positive filter for the second one and then click the first filter, the button appears in that filter and you can select Is or Is not.

      • The default filter is the positive filter.
      • This option isn't available in the filter in the History tab.

      The filters by different record fields can't be applied in the same filter. For example, the filter by Owner, the filter by Owner.Location, and the filter by Owner.First name must be in separate filters.

      Once you have added a filter by a record field of a selected record type, when you select that record type as a filter again, only the related fields option is available.

      If the field selected for the filter is a text or numeric value that isn't selected from a list, for example First name or Global Id, it's not possible to enter multiple values for the filter.

    • Text fields

      For text fields:

      • Select the field.

      • Select one of the following operators such as Contains, Does Not contain, Starts With, Ends With, Is Empty, Is Not Empty, In, and Exact Match.

      • Type a string in the text box and press Enter. 

        The operators are applicable to Small text, Medium text, Email, and URL types. They are supported in Agent Interface, Service Portal, and Mobile. The filter treats the input values as case-insensitive and accepts both uppercase and lowercase characters.
        Operators description

        Operators

        Description

        Examples

        Contains

        Displays all records where the specified field contains the search string.

        If you select the Title field and then select Contains, the filter displays only records with a value in the Title field.

        Does Not Contain

        Displays records where the specified field either does not contain the search string or is empty.

        If you select the Name field and then select Does Not Contain, the filter displays records where the Name field does not contain the specified value.

        Starts With

        Displays records where the specified field starts with the search string.

        If you select the Request Type field and then  select Starts With, the filter displays records with the starting with specified search value.

        Ends With

        Displays records where the specified field ends with the search string.

        If you select the Title field and then  select Ends With, the filter displays records with the ending with specified search value.

        Is Empty

        Displays only records where the text field has no value.

        If you select the Service field and then select Is Empty, the filter displays only records with no value in the Title field.

        Is Not Empty

        Displays records where the text field contains a value (not a null value). 

        The system displays the Is Not Empty option only when at least one positive filter exists in the filter panel.

        If you select the Title field and then select Is Not Empty, the filter displays only records with a value in the Title field and excludes records with no value.

         

        In

        Displays records containing the selected value.

        If you select the Title field and then select In, the filter accepts single, multiple, and bulk paste values and displays records that match any of the selected search values. When entering multiple search values, separate them with commas.

        Exact Match

        Displays only records that exactly match the title in the text.

        If you select the Title field and then select Exact Match, the filter compares values exactly and displays only records that match the search value.

    • Date fields

      For date fields:
      • Select the field. A dialog box appears.
      • Select one of the following date field options such as Today, Yesterday, Past week, Past Month, Past year, Tomorrow, This month, Next week, and Next year. You can also customize the dates selection by choosing the option Choose dates.
      • Click outside the filter area. The record list displays the records matching the filter criteria. You can repeat the same actions to add more fields to the filter.

Click the Delete button to remove an individual filter. Click Clear All to remove all filters. The system automatically refreshes the record list when you clear one or more filters.

Filtering records using any of the date field values do not always give expected results. This happens because the system saves the date as a timestamp that defaults to midnight (12:00 AM GMT), while the filtering logic uses the local time zone to define the date field values range. For example, if a date is saved as March 5, 2025, 11:51 PM GMT, and the system interprets Today based on the local time zone, the saved timestamp may fall outside the expected range for Today in that time zone.

As a result, records with matching calendar dates might not be retrieved. This behaviour is due to how date and time zones interact in filtering logic. To ensure consistent results, it is recommended to adjust the filter to cover the entire GMT day (from 12:00 AM to 11:59 PM GMT). This action includes all relevant records.

Use of My Groups

It is recommended to have the user member of only few hundreds of groups (not more than 500 user groups) to ensure optimal performance for data retrieval when applying filters with "My Groups" to view the records assigned to the groups the currently logged-in user is a member of.

When a Group entity link (an entity link with Reference to set to Group) is used in a filter, a (My Groups) value is available. (My Groups) contains all the groups, to which the currently logged in user belongs.

For example, the currently logged-in user is a member of Group A, Group B, and Group C. The Assignment group is an out-of-the-box Group entity link. If you set Filter by of a record list/report to Assignment group = (My Groups), the result will be filtered by Group A, Group B, and Group C.  

(My Groups) can be used in:

  • A filter of a record list.
  • A filter of a report. Please note that (My Groups) can't be used in an Analytic Report currently, this is a limitation. 
  • A filter of a 1:M/M:M relationship.   
  • A filter of Customized tabs in Service Portal. Customized tabs can be enabled in Service Portal settings. 

Filter by user options

  • For the Request record type, if the Filter by field contains only one offering, its user options can be selected as one of the filters.
  • For the Incident, Change, and Release record types, if the Filter by field contains only one model, its user options can be selected as one of the filters.

Filter by column

  1. Move your mouse over any column in the record list until the Filter button appears.

  2. Click the Filter button to display a Filter selection dialog box above the toolbar. For example, select Created by to create a filter for records created by a particular user.

    The Filter button initially appears only for columns of searchable fields. After at least one searchable field has been added to the filter panel, the Filter button also appears over columns of non-searchable fields.

  3. To set filters, see Filters above.

Filter wizard

Record lists can display up to the number of records defined in the Maximum query size setting. If there are more records than this value in a record list, you are given the option to filter the records as discussed above, using the Add filter button as described above, or alternatively, using the Filter wizard.

Depending on the module you are viewing, the Filter wizard filters records by area of relevance which can be sorted by quantity, or other relevant sort orders.

  • To filter the records by a different field, select the field from the Show tiles by list.

    A subset of the filterable fields are displayed in the Show tiles by list.

  • To change the sort options, click the relevant Sort by option.

For example, in Change > Changes, if there are more records than the Maximum query size value, Service Management gives you the option to filter the changes using the Filter wizard.

When you click the Filter wizard button, the Filter wizard logically breaks the changes down into the changes that are active, and changes that aren't active, sorted by quantity.

Clicking the tile that says Yes filters the active changes further by Priority, and sorts them by descending number of changes per priority.

You can sort by priority by clicking List value.

Click the tile representing the list of records to view. The Changes record list displays only these records.

Grouping records

  1. Click the Expand button on the left of the record list.
  2. Click the Pin button to pin the grouping pane open.
  3. Click the Group button.

  4. Select the primary field by which to group the records. For example, in Change > Changes click +Add group and select Owner. The Groups tree at the bottom of the grouping pane displays the groups in a tree. Click a group to see records in that group only.

    If the field you select is record type field, for example, if you selected Owner, you can group the records by a particular Owner property. When you hover over the field, a +Related link appears next to the field name.

    Click the link and select a related property by which to group the records. For example, select First name.

    If no filter is applied, only searchable fields are displayed in the +Related field list.

  5. If Sort by these groups is selected, the records are automatically grouped. The tree below the field selection area displays the groups.

  6. To group the records further, click +Add group and select another field in the field selection box.

    For example, select Change model to group the records by change model.

    • You can select up to three grouping levels.
    • If you want to include the ENUM SET type in Group by, it can only appear in one of the three levels.
    • You can group by more than one property of a record type field.
    • As you add more grouping levels, the Groups tree displays the number of records that meet the criteria specified for each grouping level.
    • If you select an encrypted field for the grouping, part of the Groups tree may not be displayed.
    • Without a filter being applied, when you use the +Related feature, the list may not show all related fields available. This behavior is designed for performance purposes, and to work around it, you can simply apply a filter and the list will include all related fields. 

  7. To change the order of the grouping levels, click a group and use the arrow buttons to move it up or down in the grouping levels.

    The Groups tree is realigned to reflect the change in the grouping level order.

  8. To remove a grouping level, click the group by field and click the Delete button.

    When you remove a grouping level, the grouping level below it's automatically promoted and the record list is refreshed.

If the grouping results in more than 200 groups, you must refine your filter.

  • For the Request record type, if the Filter by field contains only one offering, its user options can be selected as one of the group-by fields.
  • For the Incident, Change, and Release record type, if the Filter by field contains only one model, its user options can be selected as one of the group-by fields.

Sort order view

The sort order view shows the results of the following sort-by values. The number of records with that sort value appears in parentheses ( ).

All
Critical (1)
Total loss of service (1)
Initial Support (1)
Low (5)
Slight disruption (5)
Initial support (2)
Validate (1)
Classify (2)
